node.title: Petra Mayer, Books Editor for NPR and ‘Resident Nerd,’ Dies at 46
node.alt: Petra Mayer in 2019. Before her tenure as a books editor, she was an associate producer and director on the weekends for “All Things Considered.”
node.description: Ms. Mayer reported on Comic-Con and contributed to Book Concierge, NPR’s literary recommendation tool. She gravitated toward science fiction, romance and fantasy.
node.content: ["Petra Mayer, a books editor for NPR and self-described \u201cresident nerd\u201d who delighted readers with her musings about science fiction, comics and cats, died on Saturday at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md. She was 46.", "Her death was confirmed by her mother, Elke Mayer, who said on Sunday that the cause was a pulmonary embolism.", "Ms. Mayer joined NPR\u2019s books team in 2012 and worked on the culture desk, according to the public radio network, which reported her death on Saturday.", "The announcement prompted an outpouring of tributes to Ms. Mayer, who reported on Comic-Con and contributed to Book Concierge, NPR\u2019s literary recommendation tool.", "\u201cPetra was NPR through and through,\u201d Nancy Barnes, NPR\u2019s senior vice president for news, said in an email to the staff on Saturday that was reported by the public radio network.", "In a statement on Sunday, NPR said that Ms. Mayer had left an indelible mark.", "\u201cThis is a heartbreaking loss for all of us at NPR, our member stations and the millions of listeners in the public radio family,\u201d the statement said. \u201cPetra\u2019s passion for her work, her love for her colleagues and her joy sharing books with public radio listeners have made a lasting impact.\u201d", "Before her tenure as a books editor, Ms. Mayer was an associate producer and director on the weekends for \u201cAll Things Considered,\u201d the radio network\u2019s flagship news program, according to NPR. She had also worked as a production assistant for \u201cMorning Edition\u201d and \u201cWeekend Edition Saturday.\u201d", "In an interview on Sunday, Elke Mayer said that her daughter had been drawn to a radio career while studying at Amherst College, where she earned a bachelor\u2019s degree in history in 1996, according to her LinkedIn profile.", "\u201cShe could have progressed to management very easily, but she loved to do the actual work,\u201d Ms. Mayer said. \u201cShe loved to interview authors.\u201d", "Ms. Mayer said that her daughter relished assignments like covering Comic-Con, where she crossed paths with celebrities and characters.", "Beth Novey, an editor and producer for NPR, told the public radio network that Petra Mayer \u201cwas always up for anything \u2014 whether it was taking on a last-minute edit, dressing up as the A.P. style guide for Halloween or making a hedgehog out of cheese for an intern farewell party.\u201d", "Ms. Novey said on Twitter that Ms. Mayer was supposed to join her for brunch on Saturday. \u201cShe had (of course) promised to bring something \u2018stupidly elaborate\u2019 that she had seen on Great British Bake Off,\u201d Ms. Novey wrote.", "After graduating from Amherst, Ms. Mayer received a master\u2019s degree in broadcast journalism from the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, according to her LinkedIn profile.", "Ms. Mayer grew up in Washington, D.C. In addition to her mother, she is survived by her father, Jeffrey L. Mayer, and her partner, Josh Drobina.", "Elke Mayer said that her daughter used her position to highlight more diverse authors. She also fought for paid internships, her mother said.", "Some of the stories that she covered could be heavy, though.", "\u201cPetra was the go-to person if anybody in the arts died,\u201d her mother said. \u201cShe would write the obit and it would be on the air in an hour.\u201d"]
